An idiom is an expression that conveys something different from its literal meaning, and that cannot be guessed from the meanings of its individual words. ‚ÄúBetween a rock and a hard place‚Äù is an idiom that means ‚Äúin a difficult or bad position with no good way of getting out of it.‚Äù What makes an idiom different from a figure of speech is that its nonliteral meaning is already familiar to speakers of the language. But what is idioms without a figure of speech, you see. A figure of speech is a phrase amongst using words that are in an expressive idea in imaginative way. Unlike an idiom, it is easier to understand a figure of speech unless you were dropped.
